<FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> 
Federal Court
Tremblay-Lamer, J.
February 29, 2008.
Counsel:
Nataliya Dzera, for the applicant;
Alain Langlois, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Waice Ferdoussi, Attorneys, Montréal, Quebec, for the applicant.
John H. Sims, Q.C., Deputy Attorney General of Canada,Montréal, Quebec, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary. Any footnotes found in this case will appear below end of document.

[1]
Tremblay-Lamer, J.
: This is an application pursuant to subsection 72(1) of the
Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
, S.C. 2001, c. 27 (the Act), for judicial review of a decision of a visa officer (the "officer"), dated June 1, 2007, wherein the officer refused the applicant's application for a temporary resident visa in the visitor class (a "visitor's permit").
BACKGROUND

[2]
The applicant is a citizen of Pakistan. She applied for a visitor's permit in order to attend her granddaughter's wedding. The application was received along with a letter of invitation from the applicant's grandson at the Canadian High Commission in Islamabad, Pakistan on May 22, 2007.

[3]
The officer refused the application, checking off the boxes corresponding to the following two reasons on the standard refusal letter:
 You have not satisfied me that you meet the requirements of Regulation 179: that you would leave Canada at the end of the temporary period if you were authorized to stay. In reaching this decision I considered your ties to your country of residence/citizenship balanced against factors which might motivate you to stay in Canada.
 You have not provided sufficient documentation to support your/your host's income and assets.

[4]
In the present case, the applicant challenges the officer's findings that she would not leave Canada at the end of an authorized stay, and that she had not provided sufficient documentation to support her or her host's income and assets. As these findings are highly fact-based, the standard of review applicable is that of patent unreasonableness (
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  [2006] F.C.J. No. 578 (QL), at para.1;
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  [2005] F.C.J. No. 529 (QL), at para. 6).

[5]
Accordingly, the officer's findings will remain undisturbed unless they are "clearly irrational" or "evidently not in accordance with reason"
( <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> , at pp. 963-64).

[6]
At the outset I find it useful to examine the scope of discretion within which the factual findings at issue were made. An indication of the scope of discretion can be found in the objectives of the Act and the ministerial guidelines (
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (QL), at para. 67).

[7]
The objectives of the Act suggest that family reunification is an important consideration. Particularly, section 3.(1)(d) stipulates that one of the objectives of the Act is "to see that families are reunited in Canada". Instructively, in
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (QL), at para. 11, in the context of the previous Act, Gibson J. held that "the wording of this paragraph is broad enough to encompass the reunion in Canada of Canadian citizens and permanent residents [...] with their close relatives from abroad." Moreover, in <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> ,
supra
, at paras. 8-9, Pinard J. cited these comments with approval in the context of the current Act.

[8]
On the issue of the importance of family reunification in the discretionary decision-making context, the applicant has drawn to the Court's attention to the associated ministerial guidelines. Specifically, section 5.13 of Chapter 11 of the Overseas Processing Manual, (the "OP 11 manual"):
Parents and grandparents
In April 2005, the Minister of Citizenship and Immigration made a policy decision to encourage visa officers to be more flexible in issuing temporary resident visas (TRVs), including multiple entry visas, to parents and grandparents:
 who have applications for permanent residence in process, and
 who wish to visit but do not intend to immigrate to Canada.

[9]
A review of the CAIPs notes indicate that the visa officer was conscious of the fact that the applicant had 4 children in Pakistan, had travelled abroad previously to Saudi Arabia, had a son in Canada who was out of status, and a grandson who was a Canadian citizen. Further, the officer noted that the tax documentation from the grandson and his wife indicated a "decent income", but no proof was provided of the grandson's or his wife's employment and/or savings, or proof of the applicant's funds.

[10]
The affidavit submitted by the visa officer, dated September 24, 2007 expands upon the CAIPs notes. Particularly, the officer indicates at para. 9, that because the applicant's son had remained in Canada without status, she might be willing to do the same. Further, at para. 10, he asserts that based on his knowledge of certain cultural practices in Pakistan, specifically that widowed elderly women normally live with their sons and not daughters, the fact that the applicant's only son was living in Canada was a concern. He also indicates at para. 13, that the applicant's trip to Saudi Arabia is not usually considered to be major international travel.

[11]
With respect to the first finding, that the officer was not convinced that the applicant would leave Canada upon expiry of the relevant period, I find the officer's conclusion to be patently unreasonable.

[12]
First, the fact that her son was in Canada out of status cannot be used to impute similar conduct to the applicant. People are to be judged according to their own behaviour, not on that of their family members.

[13]
Second, while I appreciate the insights that the officer may have gained through his time Pakistan, the mere fact that elderly widowed women normally, in the view of the officer, live with sons and not daughters, cannot be used to attack the bona fides of the applicant's application. This type of gross generalization is patently unreasonable.

[14]
Third, the officer disregarded the applicant's previous trip to Saudi Arabia, stating that "a trip to Saudi Arabia is not usually considered to be major international travel in the context in which I assess applications for temporary residence". With respect, a trip from Pakistan to Saudi Arabia is international travel.

[16]
For these reasons, the application for judicial review of the visa officer's decision is granted. The decision of the visa officer is quashed. The matter is remitted back for re-determination by a different visa officer.
JUDGMENT

[17]
THIS COURT ORDERS that
the application for judicial review of the visa officer's decision is granted. The decision of the visa officer is quashed. The matter is remitted back for re-determination by a different visa officer.

179. The officer issues a temporary resident visa abroad if, following a check, the following elements are established:
has
) the foreign national has made the request, in accordance with these regulations, under the category of visitors, workers or students;
b
) he will leave Canada at the end of the authorized period of stay applicable to him under Section 2;
c

statutes: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act , S.C. 2001, c. 27
Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations , SOR/2002-227
legal_issues: Judicial review of administrative decisions regarding temporary resident visa applications.
Standard of review applicable to fact-based findings in immigration proceedings.
Whether an immigration officer's assessment of an applicant's intention to leave a country after a temporary stay is reasonable.
Admissibility of evidence regarding family ties and potential immigration intentions in temporary resident visa applications.
Acceptable evidence of financial resources to support a temporary stay.
Use of generalizations about cultural practices in assessing visa applications.
The extent to which the conduct of family members can be considered when evaluating an individual's visa application.
Interpretation and application of statutory provisions and policy guidelines related to temporary resident visas.
Discretionary power of visa officers in considering family reunification as a factor in visa applications.
factual_background: An applicant, a citizen of Pakistan, applied for a temporary resident visa (visitor's permit) to Canada.
The application was submitted on May 22, 2007, to the Canadian High Commission in Islamabad, Pakistan, and included a letter of invitation from the applicant's grandson.
The applicant intended to visit Canada to attend her granddaughter's wedding.
A visa officer refused the application on June 1, 2007, citing concerns that the applicant would not leave Canada after the authorized stay and insufficient documentation regarding income and assets.
The applicant has four children residing in Pakistan.
The applicant previously travelled to Saudi Arabia.
The applicant's son resides in Canada but is not in legal status.
The applicant's grandson, a Canadian citizen, and his wife provided tax documentation, which the officer deemed insufficient as it lacked proof of employment and savings.
The visa officer noted cultural practices in Pakistan regarding elderly widowed women living with their sons as a factor in their assessment.
The applicant submitted an affidavit expanding on the initial assessment notes.

Applicants: The officer's finding that the applicant would not leave Canada at the end of her authorized stay was unreasonable.
The officer improperly used the applicant's son's immigration status to suggest the applicant might also overstay her visa.
The officer's generalization about elderly widowed Pakistani women living with their sons was unreasonable and undermined the application's credibility.
The officer disregarded the applicant's previous international travel to Saudi Arabia.
The officer unreasonably required proof of the applicant's personal funds, given satisfaction with the host's income and the applicant's age (80s).
Family reunification is an important consideration under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and ministerial guidelines, specifically OP 11 regarding parents and grandparents.
The Minister's policy encourages flexibility in issuing temporary resident visas to parents and grandparents who wish to visit but do not intend to immigrate.
Respondents: The applicant had not satisfied the requirements of Regulation 179, specifically demonstrating she would leave Canada at the end of her authorized stay.
The applicant had not provided sufficient documentation to support her or her host's income and assets.
The applicant's son was in Canada out of status, raising concerns about the applicant's intentions.
Cultural practices in Pakistan suggest the applicant might prefer to remain in Canada to live with her son.
The applicant's trip to Saudi Arabia was not considered significant international travel.
No proof was provided of the grandson's or his wife's employment and/or savings, or proof of the applicant's funds.

court_analysis: The court reviewed the visa officer’s decision under the standard of patent unreasonableness, recognizing the fact-based nature of the findings and the officer’s discretionary power within the framework of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

The court found the officer’s conclusion that the applicant would not leave Canada to be patently unreasonable, primarily because the officer improperly imputed the conduct of the applicant’s son (who was out of status in Canada) onto the applicant herself, violating the principle of judging individuals on their own merits.

The court rejected the officer’s reliance on cultural generalizations regarding elderly widowed women in Pakistan living with their sons, deeming this a ‘gross generalization’ and an unreasonable basis for questioning the applicant’s intentions.

The court considered the applicant’s prior travel to Saudi Arabia as evidence of international travel experience, contradicting the officer’s dismissal of it as not being ‘major international travel.’

Regarding the financial documentation, the court determined it unreasonable to require proof of the applicant’s personal funds when the officer had already deemed the host’s income ‘decent,’ particularly given the applicant’s age (80s). The court referenced OP 11 manual which allows for consideration of a combination of documents and did not require all listed documents to be provided.

The court emphasized the importance of family reunification as an objective of the Act, citing section 3(1)(d) and relevant case law, and noted the ministerial guidelines encouraging flexibility in issuing visas to parents and grandparents with family in Canada.
Based on these findings, the court granted the application for judicial review, quashed the visa officer’s decision, and remitted the matter to a different visa officer for re-determination.
final_outcome: The application for judicial review of the visa officer's decision is granted.
The decision of the visa officer is quashed.
The matter is remitted back for re-determination by a different visa officer.
